Video Title: Blessed Christmas Wishes from the Dilmah Family 2025
Transcript: Hello friends, as we celebrate Christmas, things that are happening in the world around us demand reflection on what truly matters. Values, purpose and how we can positively impact people and nature. Our grandfather wanted to make the world a better tea and by better he meant kinder, better for our health, better for nature and better tasting. He meant it sincerely, which is why Dilma has a foundation of quality and integrity with a heart of kindness. My father's dream became reality 40 years ago. It has now become the global mission for the family to touch the lives of hundreds of thousands of less fortunate people every year through our work in tea, tourism and cinnamon. Business must serve humanity. Life without purpose is meaningless. So for us this blessed season is as much about hope as it is about giving. We cannot live without hope. Yet conflict chaos and inequality around the world are pushing many towards hopelessness The coolest thing about all this is that the happiness the strength the resilience we all seek comes more easily from giving than from receiving. It's the truth, something we learnt from our grandfather's legacy of kindness. We're a family business. We believe in the transformative power of tea. Every cup presents our respect for nature and our generational commitment to quality, integrity and purpose. It's you, our customers around the world, that help us to translate that purpose into impact. True joy comes from giving. Ours is a powerful partnership in giving and receiving. Every cup, a cup of kindness. Taste and goodness with the assurance of kindness. From us all, Merry Christmas! And a happy 2026!
Summary: The family‑owned tea, tourism, and cinnamon business was founded 40 years ago, originating from the founder’s grandfather’s vision of healthier, kinder, and more sustainable products. Its stated global mission is to assist hundreds of thousands of less‑fortunate people each year through those three sectors. The company emphasizes quality, integrity, and environmental respect, attributing its impact to worldwide customers. A holiday message references the upcoming year 2026.

Shaheen met the $1 million goal after twelve months, prompting weekly performance updates from Fernando regarding weekly sales, including a product referred to as “Dilma.” Fernando expressed satisfaction with the achieved milestone.

Video Title: Dilmah: 40 years, 40 stories - Koshy Mathew
Transcript: My association with Dilma started way back in 2001. I had reached the country and we were into FMCG distribution and an ex-colleague of mine actually reached out to me and he had completed a research on tea brands internationally and he said, you know what, there is this lovely brand from Sri Lanka called Dilma which is really going to be the future of tea. And I then reached out to Mr. Fernando and he said, look, you're welcome to come and experience what Dilma is all about. And before you knew it, I was on the next flight to Colombo wherein I met Mr. Fernando and Dilma. Now it's almost 20 years later, 20, 25 years later. We're very proud to say that we've come a very long way since then. and we are the market leaders with Dilma in the premium restaurants, cafes and hotels in the UAE, something that we are very proud of. Over the years I've shared a very close relationship with Mr. Fernando. He been there for me through ups and downs in life always giving me sound advice when I needed the most And this is something that I will never forget The thing which I always remember about him is his humility. You know, despite the great person that he was, he has always remained humble. And that's something that he has actually passed on through the generations, both with Dilhan and now with Amrit coming in from the third generation. They stay grounded, they stay humble, and that for me, the true values of Dilma. And now when I see Amrit on the stage with Dilhan, it's like a flashback for me where I see the same Mr. Fernando and Dilhan all those years back. And it's like the same rerun which is happening. Dude, try it. You know, one thing that I have not come to terms with is coming to Colombo and not having to get to see Mr. Fernando. That is something that a void which will never be filled. I do miss his infectious smile and his sound advice that he used to give every time that I met him on the numerous occasions, either when I was in Colombo or when he traveled through Dubai. That void will never be filled. Thank you.
Summary: In 2001, after an ex‑colleague’s research identified Dilma as a promising Sri Lankan tea brand, the speaker traveled to Colombo and met its founder, Mr. Fernando. Over the next two decades, Dilma expanded into the United Arab Emirates and became the market leader in premium restaurants, cafés, and hotels. The speaker maintains a long‑standing personal relationship with Mr. Fernando, noting his humility and mentorship, which he says have been passed to second‑generation leader Dilhan and third‑generation leader Amrit. Following Mr. Fernando’s death, the speaker remarks that his absence leaves an unfilled void.

Video Title: Nature in Conversation in the Netherlands
Transcript: There's a very special ingredient that illuminates the work of the artisan and that's nature. It's nature that gives brightness to tea, it's nature that gives intensity and flavor, gives the taste adventure. But it's also nature that gives us the possibility to personalize, to enhance teas in different ways. Now that brings me to this beautiful location. And here I am in the Netherlands. And here's Kira. It's a pleasure to meet you. You have a beautiful garden. Thank you. So nice to meet you too. I'd like to know a little bit more about what you're doing here. Do you think you could show me around a little bit? Yes, well we have a very special sage which is called in Dutch Bontesali which means a colourful sage and it's a different type of sage than the usual sage that we use in cooking. It's minty, it's complex, it's got a little citrus. It's beautiful, that's fantastic. Now let's go and have a look at your rosemary. I think the wonder of rosemary is also the fact that it is so good for human health, for cognitive ability. What is it about the garden that enthousins you so much It like a communication with nature And I feel the happiest when I in that interaction in connection with nature in that quiet You know, we taste 10,000 teas each week in Sri Lanka. and the incredible thing is from day to day the teas change because of rainfall of sunshine and this is the beauty and I really value your comment about communication with nature because it is that and it is that nature the influence of nature in what we do that makes it so very special but thank you Kira. You're welcome, thank you. So in this cup I have a combination of the nature, the people, the heritage of Sri Lanka and our tea making tradition taking us back to a different time. But also I have a connection with the nature here in the Netherlands and this beauty that surrounds us. And that combination of taste is what makes tea so extraordinarily special. Nature, the fingerprint of nature, goodness, anti-stress and so much more. Who can think of something greater? Cheers.
Summary: The speaker, while in the Netherlands, meets Kira, who tends a garden featuring a Dutch sage called Bontesali (“colorful sage”) and rosemary noted for cognitive health benefits. They discuss how nature influences tea characteristics, citing that the speaker’s company samples 10,000 teas weekly in Sri Lanka, with flavor variations driven by rainfall and sunshine. The conversation emphasizes a “communication with nature” that links the Dutch garden’s herbs to the heritage and anti‑stress qualities of Sri Lankan tea. The combined sensory profile is presented as a distinctive product of both locales.

Video Title: Dilmah: 40 years, 40 stories - Daron Curtiss
Transcript: Once you test my Dilma, you test... It was 1992. I get a call from a Meryl J. Fernando. He was casting for an advertising agency in New Zealand. I said, okay, how about coming into the agency and talking to us? And when he arrived, I asked him, how did you find out about us? He said, oh, I found you in the yellow pages. And I said, Meryl, I really need time with you. We need time for you to tell you a story, to get a feel for the tea industry. We knew little about it. So Meryl gave us his time, talked about the tea industry, and from that we gained a lot of information and, importantly, a lot of feel for Meryl and what Meryl was like as a person. So when Meryl came back the next time, we presented him with television commercial, magazine advertisements, and the suggestion that he promotes his own brand. Meryl's personality and the way that he spoke passionately about Dilma was something no actor, no one else could do. Meryl was very reluctant to go on television. And so he said, I'm away for a few days down on the South Island. When I come back, I'll give you my decision. So when Meryl came back he said he'd be happy to do the television commercial and what he said is I'm here for another three days, you need to do it then. Of course getting a crew together in three days and a location, a script that was signed off by TVNZ it was a bit of work to be done and it was Easter We presented him with the location and the script and he changed one or two words and he sat down on the couch and started with his television commercial I have devoted 43 years of my life. At first he was rushing, you know, he was very passionate about his brand. He wanted to sell his product and he started off very quickly and so we had to stop him and get him to calm down, slow down and deliver that real lovely delivery that he's got in his voice. Beautiful timber. So when Meryl was halfway through he stopped, he changed a few more words and then he carried on delivering his natural delivery to camera. I promise to give you the best salon tea. It was wonderful. During our meetings we'd also put to him about a line he would say to us was try it, you must try it. And to customers we'd hear him say try it, you must try it. So we shortened that down to do try it. Do try it. And so that was the first time Meryl delivered his line to TV in 1994. And since then, the brand has grown from strength to strength, and we're proud to be part of it. Now, here we are today celebrating 40 years of Dilma. Meryl's family is following in his footsteps. They continue in the tradition of making the world a better tea and making a stand for quality, for taste, for humanity and a better world. As my friend Meryl would say with a cup of duma in his hand, do try it.
Summary: In 1992 the agency received a call from Meryl J. Fernando, who had found them in the Yellow Pages while seeking work for a New Zealand advertising campaign. After briefing him on the tea industry, the agency produced television and magazine concepts and invited Fernando to promote his own brand, culminating in a rushed three‑day shoot in 1994 with a script approved by TVNZ that featured his line “I have devoted 43 years of my life” and the shortened slogan “do try it.” The commercial aired in 1994, after which the Dilma tea brand experienced sustained growth and is now marking its 40th anniversary. Fernando’s family continues to manage the brand, emphasizing quality, taste, and social responsibility.

Inspired by the vision of the late Meryl J. Fernando, founder of Dilma Tea and a passionate advocate for environmental stewardship, this initiative seeks to restore the land now shaped by tea. Led by a dedicated team of Sri Lankan ecologists and forestry experts and supported by Dilma Frank Linia Foundation and Rajarata University of Sri Lanka, the project aims to reconnect two isolated forest reserves, Niharakhanda and Valanghanda. Video Title: Dilmah: 40 years, 40 stories - Roshan Tissaaratchy
Transcript: is not just theoretical but is done in practice to achieve success. Meryl G. Fernando, in my mind, is a one in a billion person. Even though he was a founder, chairman and CEO, he brought his two sons into the business. With the two sons together, we saw a formidable team. Another element which I will never forget and which gave me a lot of encouragement and motivation was his belief in this country, Sri Lanka or Ceylon. He truly believed in the concept and in the product Ceylon tea. When I first started working with Mr. Vaviljo Fernando, I realized what a great achievement he has made not only for himself or for the brand, but for our country. As he took from this small country, Sri Lanka, a brand to 100 countries across the world.
Summary: Meryl G. Fernando, founder, chairman and CEO of the Dilma tea brand, led the company for 27 years, emphasizing deep product knowledge and rigorous standards. Under his leadership and later together with his two sons, Dilma expanded from Sri Lanka (Ceylon) to export its tea to approximately 100 countries. He was known for personally testing teas in a white kit and apron, using that expertise to develop successful recipes and drive commercial growth. An employee who worked 27 years with the firm described the period as a 40‑year corporate history marked by a “don‑can‑say‑can” attitude and a strong belief in Sri Lankan tea.

I've been learning how to improve processes, solve challenges, while growing my skills in such a supportive environment. So what I really love is working with a lot of teams and gaining real in that big failure. Working at DERMA never felt like working in a corporate setting. I always felt like I was part of a family.
Summary: The speaker describes their first internship at DERMA as a foundational experience. They report learning to improve processes, solve challenges, and develop skills within a supportive environment while collaborating with multiple teams. They note that the workplace culture felt more like a family than a typical corporate setting.

Video Title: A Journey of Authenticity & Innovation – Dilmah Australia 2025
Transcript: For 40 years I've been visiting Australia, mostly with my father. We always talked about authenticity, we talked about tea growers, we talked about the passion, we talked about soils and we talked about the fingerprint of nature. And this time, 40 years since my father first launched Dilma, we're talking about innovation. but innovation that's grounded in authenticity, grounded in the passion of tea growers, in our quest for stewardship of soils, of livelihoods and all of those great things that form the definition of value, the 21st century definition. Not value as in the case of discounts and price, but true value. Value expressed in significance, the lives of people, their soils, the biodiversity, and all of those great things. Our commitment as tea growers is to offer you a combination of innovation, authenticity, respect for nature, tradition, natural wellness, all of those things that make tea the greatest herb the world has ever known.
Summary: The speaker has visited Australia for 40 years, initially with his father, who launched the tea brand Dilma. Their discussions have centered on authenticity, tea growers, soil stewardship, and the ecological “fingerprint” of nature. They now emphasize innovation that remains grounded in these authentic practices and in preserving biodiversity, livelihoods, and soil health. The growers’ commitment is to deliver tea that integrates innovation, tradition, natural wellness, and respect for the environment.

Video Title: Dilmah: 40 years, 40 stories - John Burton
Transcript: 1985 our Labour government disbanded all the import controls and therefore you could start bringing in tea bags. Previously it was just tea chairs so I immediately went to Merrill we started selling his tea bags under the supermarket labels. We were doing a really good business. But then in about 1988, Meryl said to me, look, there's no real future in bulk tea. You know, you're doing well on the tea bags. Why don't we set up a new brand? And I said, look, you must be joking. We can't do that in our market. It's so difficult with all the other competitors. So Meryl said, no, no, can you please do this? And I agreed. So I was probably aged 29 and he was aged 59. And most people at 59 are thinking about retortaring, but no, no, not Meryl. So then we started preparing ourselves. He'd just started in Australia. We started increasing sales. Why? You ask why? Because the quality of the tea from Meryl was spectacular. We used to be able to sell it because we could say to them, it's the tea that you remembered, not a blended, it was a pure Sri Lankan tea. If you go back over our history, most of our teas did come from Sri Lanka and Meryl was just bringing them the tea they remembered. Now what we did in 95 was quite spectacular we started to put Merrill on the screen Do try it And that when the do try it ad came into place 1995, 30 years ago. Why I know it, because it's the year I got paralyzed. Anyway, that didn't stop us. And then our sales started to improve. 9% market share, 15% market share. And you know, things started to move. And then we became market leader. Gosh, that was an immensely proud moment. Because I was the one who said to me, you'll be mad because of these. But no, no, we became market leader. And we've been the market leader for over 15 years now. You know, Meryl didn't take no for an answer. He was certainly strong in his views. He had very good tea. He said what he was going to do. and I got on very well with them. You know, we formed Duma New Zealand and that was the starting point. And our families are very proud of the change of the generation, of the legacy Merrill has created, and especially in our two families and the way we move forward. We'll be involving my daughter who works in the business And, you know, we will use her to take the generational change forward. Most of my staff on the Doolmaar side have been with me for a very long time because they understand the company, they understand its philosophy, and they like it. They like what's going on, and they like what Doolhaan is now trying to do.
Summary: In 1985 the UK Labour government removed import controls, enabling the speaker’s company to sell Merrill’s tea bags under supermarket labels. After Merrill proposed a new pure‑Sri‑Lankan tea brand in 1988, the partners (aged 29 and 59) launched it, and in 1995 a “Do Try It” television campaign boosted sales, raising market share from 9 % to 15 % and establishing the brand as the New Zealand market leader for more than 15 years. The business later formed Duma New Zealand and is planning a generational transition that includes the founder’s daughter. Most staff have remained with the company for many years, reflecting continuity of its philosophy.

Video Title: Dilmah: 40 years, 40 stories – Tomasz Witomski
Transcript: For me, it's a wonderful thing to remember all the beautiful moments that I witnessed of Dilma's history. I remember that in 1990, Mario Fernando came with his very young son, Dilhan to our country and he said, son, this is to be your market. Take care of it. And this is how our history began. For the first time I came to Sri Lanka, I visited factory at Maligavate. and it was at that time the main place where Dilma was produced. Then there were beautiful occasions that we witnessed as a company when new products were launched, which became very important also for our company in Poland. It was T Nexty exceptional We witnessed also the first School of Clean in France in Paul Bocuse Institute. These were very important milestones for Dilma company and I'm very proud and happy that at that time I could witness these events. Mario Fernando was a very nice person. Not only businessman, but he always was interested in what is happening with other people. He wanted always to help. The main thing is to understand the world around, understand our customers, and learn what they require, what they want, because otherwise there is no business, there is no success in trade. I also implemented it in our company. This is the line that we keep. We always think about the people and we think how we can help them.
Summary: In 1990 Mario Fernando arrived in Sri Lanka with his son Dilhan, establishing the market that became the foundation of the Dilma company. The speaker later visited Dilma’s primary production facility in Maligavate, Sri Lanka, and observed product launches that were significant for the company’s operations in Poland. Dilma also inaugurated the first School of Clean at France’s Paul Bocuse Institute, marking another corporate milestone. Fernando emphasized understanding customers and helping people, a principle the speaker adopted in their own business.

Video Title: Future of Tea:  A Journey of Taste, Wellness & Artistry at Hilton Singapore Orchard
Transcript: Tea is rich with stories of great taste, goodness, the fingerprint of nature, the ultimate luxury. We're here in Singapore at the Hilton Orchard and we are talking tea, explaining to tea drinkers, to customers. How valuable is tea? When you look at value in a 21st century context, it's taste of course, but it's also the way tea elevates fine food. It's the way tea enhances gut health. It's the way tea contributes to managing stress and all of those things, but also giving joy, but never forgetting the fact that each cup becomes a cup of kindness because it embodies It carries in the aroma and the flavour. It carries the livelihoods. It carries the soils. It carries all of this that we as tea growers cherish. So my research focuses on flavonoids, which are the naturally occurring compounds present in tea. These compounds, once they're absorbed into the body, they fight inflammation. The latest science is showing us that drinking tea is now linked with slower or less biological aging and that those that drink tea have a lower risk of major types of chronic disease such as cardiovascular disease and dementia. So how many cups does science recommend to drink each day? Well the data shows us that around 2-3 cups per day is what you need to gain the health benefits.
Summary: The discussion took place in Singapore at the Hilton Orchard, focusing on tea’s sensory qualities, culinary pairing, gut‑health benefits, stress mitigation, and socioeconomic impact for growers. The speaker’s research centers on tea flavonoids, naturally occurring compounds that, when absorbed, reduce inflammation and are associated with slower biological aging. Recent scientific evidence links regular tea consumption to a lower risk of major chronic diseases, including cardiovascular disease and dementia. Epidemiological data suggest that drinking two to three cups of tea daily provides these health benefits.

Video Title: The Luxury of Tea, Redefined
Transcript: There is no beverage that offers a welcome as warm, natural and luxurious as fine tea. We're a family of tea growers. My father devoted his life to tea and we hand pick our tea to be certain that we use only the most tender leaves and buds. We care for them through the traditional and artisanal method of withering, rolling, fermentation and drying with a lot of love. We do this to capture the luxury in fine tea crafted with respect for nature. Our teas are blessed with the fingerprint of nature and that offers great taste and taste adventure. Brightness in the cup inspired by nature, intensity from the soil and kindness too. Because we also believe in our purpose beyond profit. Every sip of our teas is offered with the assurance of kindness to people and nature. This is our atelier where we craft the finest tea in partnership with nature. The surpassing lightness of our Nurelia peko is finessed by morning sunshine and light afternoon showers. The grand elegance of our breakfast teas from the soils temperature and winds in the Dimbula Valley. Tea is infinite in its variety and in hospitality this is magic for there is a tea that caresses the texture in fine food, a tea that dignifies flavors in haute cuisine, teas that balance sweetness on the palate and teas that cleanse. The story in each tea is inspiring. It starts in our tea nursery It continues through the ancient method of sustainable agriculture that we cherish to the fine hand picking and artisanal manufacture finally picking again at this time in our tea room where we taste 10,000 teas each week to select the perfect breakfast most elegant afternoon tea and the most majestic Earl Grey Our teas are packed in our facility which is among the most sophisticated in the world Its technology equaled by our commitment to sustainable packaging and being nature positive. That means zero emissions by 2030. Our Dilma School of Tea shares our love for tea with knowledge of nature's finest herb to help our partners express the taste and goodness in tea while elevating through gastronomy, mixology and more the experience of fine tea and herbs. Our selection of teas and herb infusions evolves continuously to offer innovative, tea-inspired experiences to delight your guests. The spectrum of taste and texture, the elegant relationship among tea and food, and the amazing variety that tea offers as an ingredient in mixology are what make tea so formidable in 21st century hospitality. And there's more for this ancient herb that was first discovered as a medicine offers incomparable health and mindfulness. A herb that is universally accepted and as comfortable in a cocktail or mocktail as in an elegantly crafted dish is also at its best savored pure. Welcome to a new world of tea.
Summary: The family‑owned tea estate uses hand‑picked tender leaves and buds, processing them through traditional withering, rolling, fermentation, and drying methods. Their product line includes the Nurelia Peko tea and breakfast blends sourced from the Dimbula Valley, and the company samples approximately 10,000 teas weekly to select varieties such as breakfast, afternoon, and Earl Grey blends. Production occurs in a highly automated facility that commits to zero‑emission operations by 2030 and employs sustainable, nature‑positive packaging. The Dilma School of Tea provides education on tea and herb infusions for partners in hospitality, gastronomy, and mixology.

Summary: The Meril J. Fernando Centre East, situated near Batiklo in the Calcutta area of Sri Lanka, occupies a 23‑acre plot purchased in 2012 and opened in 2018 after construction began in 2017. Our biodiversity, specifically in the case of Sri Lanka, elephants define our cultural and social identity, increasingly also our economic future. Knowledge of elephants and knowledge of every species connects to an understanding of their value. I'm not saying we can sell all 10 kilos of it, but the point is it creates in the mind of the consumer sitting in England, Germany, Netherlands, wherever, creates value for tea, understanding. And what does that value translate into? Translates into this, what we're doing today. Video Title: Dilmah Finest Ceylon Cinnamon
Transcript: The adventurer Marco Polo described Sri Lanka as the Isle of Spices. From Sri Lanka, the resplendent island, comes Ceylon cinnamon. No spice was considered equal to Ceylon cinnamon. Like many great rulers and products, Ceylon cinnamon has a pretender, cassia which masquerades as cinnamon. Only true Ceylon cinnamon grown and perfected in Sri Lanka offers the sophistication and goodness that has been so precious throughout history. The cinnamon bark can only be processed by expert artisans. It starts by harvesting branches from the cluster of cinnamon that is done expertly by hand using a shaped knife the harvested cinnamon must be kept moist and then scraped and rubbed before peeling and finally quilling The process is demanding, requiring time, expertise and experience. With each step being more intricate than the last, it takes years of experience and days of effort. True cinnamon is scientifically proven to be endemic to Sri Lanka. We grow Ceylon Cinema, working with rural artisans to select and produce only the finest continental grade and powdered Ceylon cinnamon. As we do in our mission with Ceylon's finest tea, we care for our cinnamon from nursery to quill. And we make sure that we work with our people and nature for kindness and sustainability. Produce that is grown with the love of an artisan and perfected with kindness to people and nature offers taste that goes beyond sensory, embodying kindness that is life-changing alongside the aroma, flavour and good health. We present only the finest Ceylon cinnamon, grown, nurtured and crafted in paradise, our Spice Island Sri Lanka, perfected for you by the Dilma family. you
Summary: Marco Polo called Sri Lanka the “Isle of Spices,” and the island has supplied Ceylon cinnamon—considered superior to all other spices—for over four millennia, including royal ceremonies in ancient Egypt. Historical records note that King Solomon sought Sri Lankan cinnamon in trade with the city of Gaul (Tarshish) around 1000 BC, and by the 1st century AD 350 g of the bark was valued at 5 kg of pure silver. The Dilma family now produces “continental‑grade” powdered Ceylon cinnamon with rural artisans, emphasizing sustainable, artisan‑driven methods.

Too little nitrogen in agricultural soils if we take out more than we put in then we have a problem Now in terms of that waste of resources it also an economic waste of money So if we take the total value of nitrogen wasted to air and water we get about 200 million tons. If we multiply that by one and a half dollars per kilogram nitrogen we get about 300 sorry, $600 billion worth of nitrogen wasted resource. Now, in the Colombo Declaration, which was agreed in your city in 2019, governments made an agreement to have the ambition to halve nitrogen waste by 2030. That would be effectively at today's prices, saving around 300 billion US dollars a year worth of resources. So why don't we do it? Why not take this obvious action? And I think it's back to this fragmentation of issues where nitrogen is a little part of everybody's problem, but we don't necessarily see the big picture. So we need to make it more visible. We need events like this to raise awareness of the importance of nitrogen pollution in its many dimensions if everybody's going to be motivated to act. So I want to come on now to talk about one form of nitrogen pollution, which we've been studying at the Dilma Climate Change Research Centre at Rila Gala Forest. And that is ammonia. Ammonia is one nitrogen and three hydrogens, NH3. It's an alkali and it's a form, basis form of nutrients. So amino acids, amines, etc. So with ammonia and ammonium, that's with four hydrogens in your soil, then plants can grow and make nutrients. But the question is how much? Too much, too little? If it's too much, we then affect sensitive biodiversity that's vulnerable to that too much ammonia. And not to forget, the ammonia is having other effects, effects forming fine particulate matter in the atmosphere. So ammonia is an alkali together with nitric acid and sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere, forming salts, ammonium sulfate, ammonium nitrate. And with other parts of particulate matter, those get deep inside our airways, shortening lives. Now, we, as I think you will have heard from Professor Nisanka, have been taking part in this South Asian nitrogen hub. all eight countries across South Asia. That means we've been looking at nitrogen in policies, nitrogen in agronomic solutions and in industrial solutions. We've been looking to raise awareness by studying key threats and we been studying the flows Now when it came to studying those key threats we selected two systems the forests and the coral reefs And why do that Basically because South Asia is a hotspot of nitrogen pollution and we think that both of those ecosystems are understudied. And there's a parallel between those, particularly with the lichens as indicators of air pollution growing on the forests. Now, perhaps you can just about see the tree behind me. The light isn't very good, But on that tree trunk are really happily growing lichens. And I'm in the clean part of Scotland with a rich biodiversity of lichens on the forests. It's an indicator of good tree health. But if I went to a more agricultural part of Scotland, then those lichens would be different. We'd see the fingerprint of air pollution having its effects. Now, if we compare the study that's been going on in Scotland, there's much more data on air quality and lichens in Scotland. And so our South Asian nitrogen hub has been bringing new evidence forward to try to understand that with two parts. The first part is looking at lichens in the Himalayan zone, the sub-Himalayan forests, with the Indo-Gandetic plain being a real hot spot of nitrogen pollution. The trees are standing with their feet in nitrogen air pollution and we expect with substantial effects. So we've been looking at the distribution of ammonia, the distributions of lichens. We're currently putting those data sets together to understand the scale of that impact. But we also wanted to look experimentally. We looked long and hard to find a site suitable for doing those experimental studies. And I'm very happy to say that with the introduction from Gotham, from the Natural History Museum, who's together with you today at Dilma, we found a great site in the Dilma Climate Change Research Centre. Without your endeavours there in establishing that centre high up on the top of the hill, it simply wouldn't be possible to do this experiment. So we had expected to do it in the sub-Himalayan zone. We found ourselves doing it in the Sri Lankan highlands. We're very happy to be there. So that experiment is proceeding. I think others after me, Ajinkia, Boudicca, Maud and others will tell you more about how that experiment is getting on and the results we're seeing from it. But what I can tell you is that this is critical evidence for us already showing that the lichens are sensitive to ammonia pollution in Sri Lanka, just as they are in the Himalayan zone, just as they are in the UK, and that this is a key signal for biodiversity change if we worried about our natural habitats And remember that is a litmus test of change because when you see the lichens changing the whole ecosystem function is changing, there'll be changes in soils, emissions of greenhouse gases, water quality issues, the whole nitrogen cycle being changed. So this is a really important test. So let's come on then to talk about solutions. I understand that Professor Nisanka will have told you some of his favourites. The point I want to make here about solutions is that there's an opportunity, particularly in agriculture, to farm better. And we're really happy to be working with you and Dilma on this and look further forward to building our conversations on how, for example, fertiliser use in Sri Lanka can be optimised more effectively. Now, a few years ago, you will know that a former president banned fertilizers in Sri Lanka. At the same time, in another policy film, I was working with the Ministry of Environment of Sri Lanka. We put forward a resolution to the United Nations Environment Assembly, building on the Colombo Declaration. That was not proposing to ban fertilizers. It was rather saying to halve that nitrogen waste. And what we mean is if you halve those losses to air, land and water, more is going to be available for your crop. So no target to reduce fertilizer inputs, but rather a target to reduce the losses. And when reducing the losses, then of course, there's an opportunity to save on the inputs because not so much fertilizer will be needed. a more efficient system saves money and good for the environment. So that points towards not only those methods we need, for example, fertilizer deep placement or urease inhibitors or nitrification inhibitors, different timing, but it also points towards the need to measure the system to find ways of cheap sampling of soil quality so that farmers can have more confidence that they don't need to apply excessive fertilizer use. So good for the pocket, good for the environment. I think here this is an opportunity for Dilma to play another leading role in the future, sharing with others across Sri Lanka, not just in the forest site, but in terms of rolling out and demonstrating those good agricultural practices. So I think I've come to the end of the time here and I just want to wish you well as you meet and discuss. It's a pleasure to be working with you with Dilma. As I say, without you, we couldn't do it. Thank you, Rishan, for hosting us. Thank you, Ashan, for managing the call and I look forward to speaking with you in person further when I'm next in Sri Lanka. Thank you. Thank you.
Summary: Nitrogen is transformed from inert atmospheric N₂ into reactive forms (e.g., ammonia, nitrates) through the Haber‑Bosch process, but about 80 % of the resulting fertilizer nitrogen is wasted, amounting to roughly 200 million t and an economic loss of ≈ US $600 billion; the 2019 Colombo Declaration set a target to halve this waste by 2030, potentially saving ≈ US $300 billion annually. In South Asia, excess reactive nitrogen—particularly ammonia (NH₃)—drives water, air, and soil pollution, contributes to nitrous‑oxide greenhouse‑gas emissions, and harms ecosystems such as Himalayan forests and coral reefs, as evidenced by ammonia‑sensitive lichens observed in both the Sri Lankan highlands (Dilma Climate Change Research Centre) and the UK. The South Asian Nitrogen Hub, involving eight countries and researchers like Professor Nisanka, is mapping ammonia and lichen distributions and conducting field experiments to quantify ecosystem impacts. That kindness is at the heart of Dilma and it is our strength and joy that our mission in tea touches the lives of hundreds of thousands of children youth women and men in Sri Lanka and beyond We have the privilege of calling ourselves an ethical family business because the work our Meril J. Fernando Foundation does in building schools, hospitals, fighting cervical and childhood cancer, enabling aspiring entrepreneurs, addressing gender imbalance and inequality. So we wanted to understand the drivers of what resulted in the recolonization. And there's these little strips of land corridors connecting them from other source populations. And so not only were they able to recolonize, but existing at very high densities. What happened and the fundamental drive is that there was a reduced conflict in the area. There was enormous amount of lethal control of carnivores for two, three hundred years in that region and so they were all but decimated. And what a meta population is, is that it's a fragmented populations of different leopards that might be disconnected from one another but the dispersing individuals are able to connect and so these land bridges and and corridors are fundamental for these populations that might locally go extinct to be able to recolonize. We covered a few areas there that how humans can play a role in protecting and growing these densities of leopard. Can you explain what a land corridor is and how it benefits the conservation of leopard? Sure, so typical conservation model is protected areas, which is fragmented. And often it's not highly effective to conserve biodiversity and especially these wide ranging mammals like leopards. And so because they exist mainly outside of protected areas, habitat connectivity is important. And what is leopard habitat might be different to what is elephant habitat, for example. So understanding what those differences are, are important to facilitate the species to be able to move. And why leopards are a good ecological indicator is that because of the high traffic level, they need to eat different prey to survive. And so automatically where they exist, those prey generally tend to thrive. And so that's what makes them a good indicator species. For example lions are very community driven and social but that means that they require a lot of space and a lot of food and so they've been restricted in South Africa to to protected areas and parcels of habitat. Video Title: Dilmah Tea Joins Fight to End Cervical Cancer in Sri Lanka
Transcript: From amongst over 8.8 million Sri Lankans at risk of cervical cancer, over 1,500 are diagnosed each year and for over 50% of them it's usually too late. Now that doesn't need to be the reality. And I'm delighted to be here in Colombo this evening to witness the signing of a historic memorandum of understanding between the MJF Charitable Foundation and the government of Sri Lanka that Rotary is an integral part of. Proud Movement, Dilma Foundation and the government of Sri Lanka combined together with Rotary to ensure that cervical cancer is either detected early or in fact prevented. We are thrilled that this project will address the issue of cervical cancer that affects and takes the lives of 700 women each year at present in this country. And to do that you need to vaccinate children in the age group 9 to 12 or so and be able to screen the older women who may already have contacted the disease Today, the new journey started to strengthen the CA Cervix screening program. So I'm sure this will help to save lives. Every business has an obligation to the purpose beyond profit, to serve their community. And so we must embrace this collective duty to ensure the wellness of women, to address inequality and poverty alleviation in every possible way. And that's our promise to the women and girls of Sri Lanka, that we, together with Rotary and the government of Sri Lanka, will work towards the eradication of cervical cancer by 2030. My father formed Dilma as a family business with the foundation of family values, primarily kindness.
Summary: Over 8.8 million Sri Lankan women are at risk of cervical cancer, with more than 1,500 diagnoses annually and over 50 % detected at a late stage, resulting in approximately 700 deaths each year. In Colombo, the MJF Charitable Foundation, the Dilma Foundation, the Proud Movement, the Sri Lankan government, and Rotary signed a memorandum of understanding to expand the CA Cervix screening program and vaccinate children aged 9–12. The partnership aims to improve early detection and prevention of cervical cancer across the country. The collaborators have set a target to eradicate cervical cancer in Sri Lanka by 2030.

Video Title: Honoring Merrill J. Fernando: A Tribute by Colombo Tea Traders' Association
Transcript: A mighty oak has fallen, but from its corns many more mighty oaks will grow. Today is a special day. We will discuss the historical aspect of it later. But let us first remember Mr. Meryl Fernando, a visionary entrepreneur and a great champion of Ceylon Tea. His profound impact on the tea world, his humanitarian efforts were recognised by international organisations and will be remembered and celebrated. Together today we acknowledge, learn from and strive to emulate his achievements. So let us commence by rising and observing a moment's silence in his memory. It's great to see leadership of the past, leadership of the future here in the room. And it's an important aspect of the CTTA. It is important that once again we understand the context in which Mr. Fernando achieved all of this and gave so much to the trade and our country at large. had a ringside seat of the progress, the ups and downs. Many of us see the great buildings, the bands on the shelves and forget the roots and how these were built one, one teabagging machine at a time, one structure at a time, building people, building brands. Many of us think that if we are lucky we come up with a pretty designed and it's going to be seen and recognized by the world. So all of us, at least speaking for myself, are students of the case study of the life of Mr. Merrill Fernando. It's a privilege indeed to be here and speak a few words at this commemorative sitting on behalf of a doyen of the Sri Lankan tea industry. I had a glimpse of, not glimpse, I read a couple of chapters of the book that he wrote just before he passed away. realized that he has joined the trade in 1950, even before I was born. And over the years, but within a short time in fact, he wanted to do something totally different from the run of things in the tea industry of Sri Lanka. He wanted to do from here what the colonial masters were doing with our product, which is going from here as a raw material. So Meryl saw things differently and went on to do what he did. And here we have in certain airlines, in many hotels around the world, many supermarkets around the world, which of course is a daunting task I can see, because he was always on PO Ceylon T. Sri Lanka was losing the Australian market, just to quote one example. And the reason being, with the nationalization that took place about two years before I joined the trade, brought in a, as Ensler would always agree with me, brought in a whole load of disaster for the industry. But by 89, 90, 92, we came back on the Australian shelves and that was through Dilma, for which from the point of the Sri Lankan tea industry and on our personal behalf of Sri Lanka Tea Board we are greatly indebted to this gentleman for what he did for Ceylon Tea Once when I met him had a discussion he told me, Niraj, when I go to a market, I go and look at the shelf and I see what is on eye level, which is where the best of the teas, the highest priced teas are stored on the shelves and I see X brand and Y brand and whatever and they are at let's say for example $5.49. I am pure Ceylon tea so therefore I will come there at $5.99 because I want to make the difference and that stuck in my mind of what he did. I raised my head to this gentleman for what he did for us during his lifetime. And I used to come to Mr. Fernando asking him to pack the tea bags for me. He always, very graciously, I used to go to him, he used to always sometimes stop his orders and pack my orders for me when it was urgent. So I will now read the citation on behalf of Chairman CTTA. As a tribute to late Desha Mane and Merrill J. Fernando, We, the Colombo Tea Traders Association, present this citation to celebrate the remarkable life and indelible contributions he has made as a true visionary and luminary in the realm of tea. His legacy is one that resonates across time and borders, a testament to his unwavering commitment to excellence, innovation and passion for tea. The journey of this legendary personality was one of fervent dedication and pioneering spirit etched into the annals of Ceylon's history. As the founder of Dilmati, an identity that brings pride to Sri Lanka, he redefined the industry landscape, transcending convention and bringing a refreshing force of authenticity to global tea culture. He championed the principles of ethical tea production and marketing, ensuring that every leaf bore not just a mark of excellence but also a story of integrity and compassion. He was immensely responsible for the growth of the value-added tea industry in Sri Lanka, as his success inspired others to follow in his footsteps. Mr. Fernando's yielding commitment to quality, combined with innovative marketing, propelled Dilma and Ceylon tea to unprecedented heights, elevating it to a name and standard admired and relished across continents. His inspiring efforts to nurture sustainability and empowered local communities epitomizes his boundless empathy, transforming the lives of countless individuals across the nation. His commitment to conservation and responsibility of cultivating standards as a testament of his foresight and sense of responsibility towards our planet. The vision of Mr. Fernando extends beyond the tea fields, touching hearts and leaving an indelible mark through his philanthropic endeavors. His commitment to education, health care, and social welfare eliminated parts of hope for those less privileged, bringing a brighter future for generations to come. We, the members of the Colombo Tea Traders Association, reflecting upon his remarkable life, stand indebted to Mr. Merrill J. Fernando for his unassailable dedication to Ceylon Tea. He will remain a beacon of inspiration for all who tread the path of excellence in marketing and in the service to humanity. In hallowed pages of history, Deshamani and Merrill J Fernando name shall forever remain unintertwined with the rolling green hills of Sri Lanka and their aromatic breezes and the cherished flavour of Ceylon tea Let us, with profound respect and gratitude, salute the life and work of this exemplary man whose contributions have enriched the lives of so many immeasurably. us rejoice in remembering his legacy so that generations to come will continue to be inspired by his dedication to Ceylon T and his commitment to serve humanity. MR. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. On behalf of my brother, our families, my colleagues, we are incredibly humbled by the Felicitation that the CTTA has extended to my father and also thank the chairman of the T-Board for his kind words. You know, every great industry is formed on the commitment and the passion of great people. Mr. Abbas Akbarali, my father, so many others who are represented by those present here and who have been in this room. For my father, his was truly a devotion, a lifetime devoted to tea. And for many of you, I think you also experienced, as did Anil, sometimes Neeraj and others, the strength and the ferocity of my father's belief in Ceylon tea. but many misunderstood that as a form of belligerence. It was to an extent because for my father there was nothing beyond quality. There was no compromise that was possible. But the assurance I have for you is that with that same belligerence, he took Ceylon T. to the world. I have stood by him, traveled with him for 20 years, initially carrying his bags, thereafter taking down notes, but always being with him amongst buyers. when he always explained, I have the finest tea in the world. It must be offered at the right value. And exactly as Niraj shared, he would always look at the competition and say, look, I'm not competing with the number one. I'm not trying to be the biggest. I want to be the best because I believe, I believe in Ceylon tea. And it is that which has given us the strength. It is that which gave us the ability to enter the Australian market with confidence, which my father did. And I must apologize, Neeraj, we had a correction. Our records were incorrect. It wasn't 1988. It was, in fact, September 1985 that Dilma entered the Australian market. And the same for New Zealand. But it is that that has given us the foundation and the courage to be able to take Dilma beyond to unconventional markets. Yes, a mighty oak has fallen. And yes, the oak is going to be perpetuated in philosophy and it is going to be emulated. And the reason for that is that the values that my father ingrained without compromise into my brother and I will, without question, continue through our generations. And I can tell you whether it concerns Ceylon tourism or Sri Lanka tourism or Ceylon tea, the standard that my father established is one that cannot be compromised because he formed such a firm foundation in our business. He formed in the foundation, in the MJF Foundation, he formed an irrevocable commitment to kindness to people, to nature. You see that manifest a couple of weeks ago in our invitation to join us in our journey in sustainability You see that in the hundreds of millions that every year are spent on the health welfare benefit on supporting entrepreneurs in Sri Lanka and more in the area of the environment. But ultimately what we should celebrate today is a great Sri Lankan who who stood for Sri Lanka, who understood the value of Sri Lanka, and who fearlessly championed that value. Whether it was confronting media in the UK, which is almost barren where it concerns Ceylon Tea, whether it concerns the US, again a similar situation, he did it with absolute conviction that Ceylon Tea is the finest on earth. Now I know we have our internal differences and our internal concerns, and Neeraj set those out much better than I could. And I think the best way to honor that memory, not only of my father, but also the other great men who formed the foundation of our great Ceylon tea industry, is to make a commitment to reforming that foundation that Neeraj mentioned is today weak and needs support. I think as Dr. Daya, as Daya Vikramatunga often reminds us, some of the basics are what contribute to the quality and are what are necessary today, even as we look to the future of our industry. but also we must remember that rebuilding that foundation is what will sustain the livelihoods of millions. And in the future, I have often tried to contemplate what could life be without Ceylon tea. It's quite difficult to comprehend. However much we say that the brand of Ceylon tea is eroded, yes it is. There is a new generation that doesn't recognize Ceylon tea. It is. But every facet of the history, the heritage, the livelihoods involved and the authenticity, the variety in Ceylon tea are perfectly aligned with the preferences and what a new generation of beverage consumer tells us, whether it is a millennial or a gen Zer. We work a lot with consumers directly and I can assure you that if we were to undertake some of those corrective actions that Neeraj shared, there is a consumer who will not only accept but embrace because our industry has an unparalleled heritage. It has an unparalleled offer in terms of the taste, the diversity, the wellness. And it has a very intricate interrelationship with the livelihoods of people. And today, conscious consumption is something that is an overriding concern in every area, in every grocery category. It is conscious, authentic, ethical, sustainable product that is winning. And it's no longer the big brands. It is the small brands that represent these with sincerity. So in conclusion, I want to thank each of you, and I want to thank the CTTA for honoring our father and Amrit's grandfather in this way. And I think that remembering that this great industry has as part of its foundation the commitment, the love, the efforts, and in my father's case, the faith of several formidable individuals, I think the best thing that we can do to honour or possibly take that citation into action is to work towards rebuilding our industry and remembering also that united we will stand, but divided we will fall.

Video Title: 2023 Christmas Wish from the Dilmah Family
Transcript: Christmas is a very special time for our family. It's not Christmas as usual this year though, because in 2023 we lost my father who ignited our family passion for tea. We celebrate his legacy at Christmas because Christmas is a time of kindness and my father's love for tea was equaled only by his desire for kindness. In that kindness which he embedded at the heart of our family business, he lives on in everything we do. He is here in our MDF Centre in Morutua, our largest and most vibrant centre invested in bringing positive change to people's lives. Every month thousands visit to learn about nature and find peace in this unique place. His kindness touches every member of our team, from the Tea Gardens to our factory, through through scholarships for the children of our workers, the integrity and respect we extend to each, and the entrepreneurship programs we offer them once that time is done with Dilma. My grandfather is here amongst the rainbow children guiding our MJF Kids program celebrating the ability of children with Down syndrome cerebral palsy and autism while giving wings to the dreams of youth and children from less fortunate communities. Our grandfather's Dilma stories echoed hundreds of times each year in the lives of each of dreams come true. My father's wish to make Dilma a business that also serves humanity is fulfilled every day across Sri Lanka and in many other countries around the world where the philosophy of kindness helps elders with palliative care, children with cancers and many others who need help. Video Title: Spreading awareness on nitrogen pollution
Transcript: South Asia has emerged as a major hotspot for nitrogen pollution and there's not a lot of policy in place to tackle that. So the first step for that is to provide scientific evidence on the basis of which policy can be formed. As a part of that, here in Sri Lanka, we have set up an experiment where we are measuring the metrological conditions at very high spatial and temporal resolution in a tropical forest, which in itself is an understudied ecosystem. The second part of our work here is the ammonia enhancement experiment, where we increase ammonia concentrations in a controlled plot, and then we study the effect on different organisms within this plot. So that has given us, it is giving us new insights on how this gas can be harmful and what its impacts can be. So far we have collected about more than one and a half year of full metrological data, which is one of the most complete data sets from this region. And the ammonia impacts, they take time to show up, so it takes about more than five years. But we done about three surveys now and we have at least three time points where we are trying to see the change in the vegetation conditions after the impact of ammonia So in tropical forests or in general forest ecosystems in South Asia are quite understudied And we don't have a lot of baseline information of what goes on inside these forests, the physical and chemical processes that occur within these ecosystems. And so using this experiment, we're providing some very baseline data and the first evidence of what these forests do and how they impact the greater environment. For future, I think this experiment will work as a platform on which other institutes can build on using this as an example because it is showing how critical this data collection is. And then even using our methodology, they can replicate the experiment elsewhere and broaden the impact of the work that we're doing. This site is also, it's a good replicate of a lot of other disturbed ecosystems across South Asia. So the results that we collect here can quite easily be applied elsewhere as well to the greater region So I think that been one of our greatest biggest achievements So we came to Sri Lanka mainly because Sri Lanka in itself is an ecologically very diverse country and there's a lot of biodiversity here which needs to be protected and conserved. This area especially around Rila Gala Forest again has a very very high species diversity which is important for the ecological balance of an ecosystem. So far we have collected about more than one and a half year of full metrological data which is one of the most complete data sets from this region and the ammonia impacts they take time to show up so that it takes about more than five years but we've done about three surveys now and we have at least three time points where we are seeing trying to see the change in the vegetation conditions as after the impact of ammonia. So we came to Sri Lanka mainly because Sri Lanka in itself is an ecologically very diverse country and there's a lot of biodiversity here which needs to be protected and conserved. This area especially around Rila Gala Forest again has a very very high species diversity which is important for the ecological balance of an ecosystem Since 2014 there was already a lot of work being done here and there had been new discoveries of lichen species and already existing large number of lichen species so that was a perfect platform for us to set up this experiment. The impacts of a given event are very far reaching and they are not regional so for example the effects of a certain event can be felt across the borders, across the continents, into other parts of the world. Also along the policy lines, countries are now trying to meet their targets according to the UN regulations and all the international conventions. Whereas some countries are better equipped to achieve their targets, other countries are not. More developed countries have better environmental monitoring capabilities which the underdeveloped and developing world is still trying to build up on. So to expedite this process and to have a more fair and equitable climate action, it is important that there is a transfer of not just knowledge but expertise on scientific measurements, monitoring, modeling across the world from where the expertise is in two parts of the world where that expertise is badly needed.
Summary: South Asia is a major hotspot for nitrogen pollution, prompting a Sri Lankan experiment that records high‑resolution meteorological conditions in a tropical forest and conducts controlled ammonia‑enhancement plots to assess impacts on vegetation and organisms. Over 1.5 years of meteorological data—one of the most complete regional datasets—have been collected, and three vegetation surveys spanning roughly five years provide the first time‑series evidence of ammonia effects. The Rila Gala Forest site, noted for high species diversity and prior lichen discoveries since 2014, serves as a replicable baseline for other disturbed ecosystems across South Asia. Findings aim to inform policy under UN environmental conventions and facilitate transfer of monitoring expertise to developing countries.

Summary: The baimu method, a Chinese technique for producing white tea from bud and first leaf, was applied for the first time in Sri Lanka on Craighead Estate. The tea originates from seedling plants introduced 140 years ago, known locally as “China Jat,” and is one of two varieties cultivated: the smaller, sweeter China Jock planted by early pioneers, and the larger Sri Lankan Assamica variant derived from Assam jungle stock. The China Jock yields a lighter, floral‑aromatic white tea distinct from the more robust Assamica type.

Video Title: The International Day for Biological Diversity - 2022
Transcript: so do Thank you. On this International Day for Biological Diversity, we are joined by a very special person who needs no introduction. Mr. Dilhan Fernando is the CEO of Dilma and he is also the chairman of the board of directors of Biodiversity Sri Lanka. So hi Dilhan, how are you? Welcome. Very good to meet you. So we'll jump straight to the questions. What is biodiversity? You know, it's a richness of life around us. When you consider the importance of biodiversity to our lives or its relevance, it is the aesthetic value of greenery that you see. It has a huge subliminal psychological impact on peace and calm. But beyond the aesthetic is a simple functional value value because it is biological diversity that not only gives us the richness of life but also fuels the ecosystem services from the clean water to clean air. It is essentially the fabric that supports us aesthetically, functionally in literally every way and for us having involvement in a tea business It is particularly so because it is biodiversity that fuels the terroir in fine wine, in fine teas and so on. Okay, so daily we are hearing news of a lot of species growing extinct. What are these numbers? How many and why is this happening? The numbers are horrific. It's estimated at a loss of around 150 species daily, with over 50% lost since 1970, and that's of vertebrates alone. It's tragic because with the loss of these species, not only do you lose the diversity of life, but also we are losing opportunities to study more about life support systems, about medicine, more that we are learning. If you look at aerodynamics, the engineers, however brilliant they are, are studying nature, for example when you look at medicines it is nature that is providing us with clues to medication And in some cases it is elements in nature that we are replicating or synthesizing to produce medicines And there is a very real and tangible impact of biodiversity on our support systems. So if you can break it down for us, why are these species disappearing? Well, it's simply overconsumption. You have overfishing, you have exploitation of resources, you have mineral exploitation, drilling in the Amazon. You have every day we are seeing horrific figures about deforestation in the Amazon. You have people eating more beef than science advises us is sustainable. We are using the resources of the earth beyond what the earth can carry. They everything has a certain sustainable level and that sustainable level is defined as the point at which all species can coexist and I think it is coexistence that should be the key because we need to respect not only the functional benefit of biodiversity for us but also the fact that in coexisting we are ensuring our survival so biodiversity is critical to this but that equilibrium point is what we have passed over consumption in everywhere poaching hunting deforestation damaging the ecosystems that sustain biodiversity okay so why is it so important and why is it so worthy of protection well with biodiversity being really the fabric of life it is providing us with food it is providing us with medicine so if you have for example a monoculture typically you will suffer the possibility that that monoculture could could have pest infestation etc if you have a biodiversity with more more contemporary sustainable concepts of for example agroforestry where you respect biodiversity you go into a more natural environment where you have better biological natural containment of pests, natural containment of some of the threats to your crops. It's a more natural, sustainable way of coexisting because in a monoculture, as an example, you will have depletion of soils. You see that in the tea industry here, whereas if you have an agroforestry model, you have better circularity, you have the plants that are nourishing the soil, the soil that is nourishing whether it is tea plants or food or flowers or whatever you are growing in it, it is a more sustainable and viable way because ultimately we want to leave the earth in a better condition or at least as good a condition as we find it for the next generation. And that sustainability and biodiversity are key to that. What is being done to preserve biodiversity and its hotspots? Well, there is the Convention on Biological Diversity which brings 196 member countries together in identifying specific areas whether it is marine or terrestrial and it is an important convention but the significance of the convention is not in the agreement that has been made at CBD but rather in its execution So the execution requires the involvement of every one of us from individuals to businesses. The definition and the information is out there. Every week we see IPCC reports, we see different UN reports that tell us about accelerated deforestation in the Amazon, accelerated poaching, overfishing, different cataclysmic situations. We also see flooding in Australia, we see fires in the northern parts of Russia, we see unnatural things happening. So you have here the problem in the latter part and the solution in the former. So hoping that people will frame the problem and the fear of what we are seeing happening around us in what is most practical as its solution in the CBD that is our hope for the future. How much do you think it will cost to kind of rescue biodiversity? Well the estimates are varied from 500 billion dollars to two and a half trillion dollars but But remember that in protecting biodiversity, we are protecting businesses, we are protecting the aesthetics, we are protecting simply life as we know it. And so the reason why some may balk at that figure and saying look two and a quarter or two and a half trillion dollars is the fact that they do not currently ascribe a value to biodiversity, but when you actually try to value biodiversity, value the role of a bee and understand the role of pollination, not only in food production, but also in every other area that contributes to human welfare and human survival, then you get a true picture. That two and a half trillion dollars is really insignificant when you look at defence expenditure, you look at subsidies to the fossil fuel industry all of which are affecting biodiversity negatively so it needs to be framed in that context so what can corporates do to help there's a lot that corporates can do to help initially I think awareness is the most important element to stimulate action so spreading awareness help people understand what is biodiversity what does it mean the conversations we had for example the pharmaceutical companies could help explain how in many cases you have squid, you have fish, you have plants that have been the inspiration or the practical idea, the scientific idea behind certain medicines. Help people understand the value of biodiversity but beyond that is the tangible action. We need to look at more sustainable business and individual so that we arrest overconsumption, so that we arrest some of the unsustainable actions we are doing. So for example you can talk about people phones Phones are so important in life today but ultimately taking the model from inspired businesses that actually talk about circularity and sustainable living maybe we don need to produce a new model every six months and when a new model of iPhone comes out perhaps we don't need to encourage people to think about the next one which is what happens you have the rumors coming out and you create aspirations. So businesses need to responsible in helping people avoid over consumption, understand the situation, because being sustainable and protecting biodiversity doesn't mean that we have to compromise anything in our current lives. It actually means the converse. It means that we are going to have richer, more healthy lives because ultimately better quality of water, better air quality. All of these plus the simple fact when you go on holiday, typically you're not going to say I'm I'm going to go and spend my time in the center of the city. You're going to go to the beautiful rural areas. You're going to go to Kandy. You're going to go to Norelia, etc. You're going to go somewhere where you can appreciate nature. That aesthetic value, particularly at this point, when people are suffering such mental health challenges, but also the fact that there is a practical functional benefit. Ultimately, what more do I need to say than plants clean the air that we breathe, mangroves clean the water, they provide fish, they nurture ecosystems for prawns and in doing so they nurture the economic benefit for the local communities. There is incredible potential in understanding and in protecting biodiversity because it has a direct benefit on our economic activity but also on our personal health and well-being. So making people aware of that, I think is critical. So Dilhan, is there anything else you would like to add? Any message you would share with the viewers? Absolutely, yes. On this International Day for Biological Diversity, the theme is a shared future for all. My advice is, let's consider when we buy a new phone, when we want to buy a new car, is it a trend, is it a fashion, is it a necessity? Now, if we focus on what we need, rather than what we want. We can have a shared future for all. We can leave the world a better place for future generations. But we can also enrich our own lives, our businesses, the livelihoods of the fishermen, the livelihoods of the farmer and the agriculturalists. So it's a very simple principle. Let's live and act sustainably by focusing on a shared future for all. So thank you Dilhan for this wonderful chat. You've enlightened us about the importance of biodiversity and how we can all play a part and how corporates can help. So I hope you were all able to learn something from this and know that we can all play a part even in our small ways to help biodiversity. Thank you.
Summary: Dilhan Fernando, CEO of Dilma and chairman of Biodiversity Sri Lanka, explained that biodiversity provides both aesthetic value and essential ecosystem services such as clean water, air, and the terroir that underpins tea and wine production. He cited estimates that roughly 150 species are lost each day and that over 50 % of vertebrate species have disappeared since 1970, attributing the decline primarily to overconsumption—including overfishing, deforestation, mineral extraction, and unsustainable beef production. The Convention on Biological Diversity, signed by 196 countries, aims to protect hotspots, but implementation requires coordinated action from individuals, businesses, and governments, with financial needs estimated between US $500 billion and $2.5 trillion. Fernando urged corporations to raise awareness, adopt circular and agroforestry practices, and prioritize need‑based consumption to support a shared, sustainable future.

Video Title: Story of Soil
Transcript: Soil, this 60-inch layer, is a reason for the air we breathe and the food we eat. If we take care of the soil, it will take care of us. Ten years ago, this was landfill for factory waste. This knowledge is too important to keep to ourselves, so we welcome and encourage visitors to learn the value of nature and understand how we can regenerate degraded land. Using soil sustainably provides the resources we need for agriculture, medicine, tourism, clean water, food security, and the air we breathe.
