Video Title: The Complexities of the Human – Elephant Conflict
Transcript: Dr. Preeti Viraj Fernando, we're honored to have you on this conversation. Thank you. And I know you like to be called Prutu. Now you have an interesting history which I want to share with our listeners. You started and qualified as a medical doctor and then you decided that the elephants were calling. You have an incredible history. You have been in Oregon University in the US. You've studied the genetic ecology and conservation of the Asian elephant. You've gone on to Columbia University in New York. You conducted research on Asian elephants and the Javan rhinos. You've done field work in Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Laos, Cambodia, Borneo and Bangladesh. But thank goodness for Sri Lanka that you decided to return. We are truly blessed that you took that decision and today you are chairman of the Center for Conservation and Research. You're also a research associate with the Smithsonian Institute and you've received the Whitley Award for Nature Conservation and Presidential Awards for Scientific Excellence. Tutu, the president downwards, countries around the world have recognized you for your commitment to elephants and today we want to talk a little bit about elephants. Welcome. Thank you, Dylan, for that long introduction. Yeah, I'm always happy to talk about elephants. We're going to start with the inevitable. You know, we read about elephants, we see them, people talk about their majesty and so on. What is it that makes elephants special? We read about emotional sensitivity, we talk about or we hear about the structure of elephant herds, how they have their emotional connection, their sensitivity in terms of their relationships and they really sound unique but please tell us what really makes elephants special? Well I don't know what's not special about elephants you know if you I mean if you look at just look at an elephant i mean it's such a huge animal i mean it's the largest animal on land and then in addition to that it has this very strange appendage called a trunk which no other animal has it's like a fifth hand so just from from appearances itself i mean the males have tusks if it's african elephants both the males and females have tusks so it's it's something that is I would say very unique just by your parents but not only that even if you look at their social structure, their intelligence, their behavior, I think practically everything about elephants is very special. There's also often talk of how elephants really mourn and grieve and feel emotional stress in many situations. Is there anything that you have to add there? Clearly, so elephants are intelligent animals. They are also animals that have the capacity to recognize individuals and perhaps recognize themselves as individuals. So, So in a way, I mean, if you look at intelligence, we consider ourselves to be the most intelligent animal on earth. And elephants are also a very intelligent animal. So they have a very, very good memory. They have a very big brain, just the size of the brain. And so I think, like I said, every way you look at an elephant, it's very special, especially their social organization. So they have a very characteristic social organization where the males and females as adults have very different social structures. The females and the young live in groups and the males leave the groups when they come into puberty about 10 to 15 years of age and as adults they are single mostly solitary animals but still even the adult males of course because they associations with the herds maybe the herd they were born into as well as other herds that are in their area. But in addition to that, now we are beginning to realize that even the males themselves have a different social structure among themselves, between the individual males. Some males are hanging out together a lot of the time. So it's something very interesting. And practically most of what is known about elephant behavior has been based on African savannah elephant. There have been some very famous researchers who have worked on them for a very long time, very famous scientists. So we have a wealth of knowledge about their behavior. And we always assumed that it was the same for Asian elephants, but what we are seeing now is that it may not be so that Asian elephants have their own types of behavior and own social organization, which in principle may be somewhat similar to African elephants, but also is quite different from African elephants. Is it correct to say that like Sri Lankan society, that elephants are a matriarchal society? Yes, absolutely. because of this what we call sexually dimorphic social structure the males and the females having different social structures the females living in groups so now based again based on African elephants it has always been assumed that there is a leader which is the oldest female in a group And so from a structural point of view, the oldest female, the group is composed of a female, her young, and their own young, and mostly the females, the female offspring, as well as the younger males. so in a single herd you might have about three generations of elephants so it has always been assumed that the oldest female the grandmother of them all or maybe even the great-grandmother of them all plays a leading role and has been named a matriarch and this is something that has been seen in African savannah elephants but when we look at the eye elephants Asian elephants as well as particular Sri Lankan elephants, we don't see a clear leadership role for the oldest female. So you can identify often the oldest female in a group, but she doesn't seem to show such a strong leadership role. And also the group, the groups in Asian elephants tend to be somewhat smaller than with African elephants. So there's a lot that we really don't know about Asian elephants, even though strange enough it's the Asian elephants that have had the closest association with people for thousands of years, but we still really don't know much about them at all. So Prutu, amongst your other accolades and recognitions, the President of Sri Lanka has invited you to find a solution to the human elephant conflict and that's a huge responsibility but the conflict itself is tragic. Is there a way that we can manage this conflict sustainably? Absolutely but it's not easy. So human elephant conflict is a very complex thing and the thing is Now, clearly when there is conflict between two groups, when it's humans and elephants or humans and humans or whatever, clearly both parties suffer from the conflict. So yes, elephants suffer and people suffer. But when it comes to human-elephant conflict, we really mostly ignore the elephant We focus practically only on the human aspect of human-elephant conflict. So the best example of that is if you look at the measures that we take to mitigate the human conflict the main methods are we capture elephants put them in a truck take them far away and dump them in some far away remote protected area We drive elephants out of the areas that they have been born and been living for generations. We drive them by force away from those lands and restrict them to some protected area and put up a fence. We distribute firecrackers to farmers to confront elephants and throw these firecrackers at them. So I'm not saying that any of these are wrong as such, but the point is these are only directed towards finding a solution or more to manage the problems that people have from elephants. And in fact, many of these measures actually cause a lot of problems for elephants. So, but looking at it, even from a people's point of view, the unfortunate thing is that we have thought that this is something very simple, that you can do one thing and solve the problem forever. But it is something very complex. I mean, people are very complex, elephants are very complex. So inevitably the conflict is a very complex thing. It differs from place to place, area to area, depending on the people, depending on the elephants, depending on the location. So there are a lot of complexity. But the main thing is there is nothing, no one thing that any one group or person can do that's going to solve this. So in order to manage the conflict, lots of agencies, lots of people have to come together and a lot of things need to be done. to be done and that needs a very strong leadership to make that happen. Putu, there's lots of discussion about elephants in zoos and so on and I know it becomes a heated argument because of the social structure that we spoke of. What is your opinion? What's your take on that is it you know from an educational research I guess a charismatic perspective is it acceptable to have two or three elephants in the zoo or what is I'm sorry I'm probably asking a difficult question and if you prefer not to answer that's fine but I'm interested to know your perspective. So yes, so there is the broader aspect of elephants in captivity per se which is and elephants in zoos are a subsection of that. So just from an elephant point of view, if you have a single animal, given that as you say that they have such a social structure, whether even the males, it's probably not a great thing for that elephant. So, and then you have degrees of captivity and the degrees of how much interaction these animals have with other animals, other elephants, as well as even people. So again, it's not a black and white thing. There's lots of shades of grey here. of shades of gray here. So currently most international zoos are going away from having one or a single animal or one or two elephants in captivity. So they are trying to form a social group if they have elephants so that they have some sort of social structure. So that I think is a good thing. But also many Western zoos particularly have become very adverse to one-on-one interaction with elephants. That's partly driven by the possible potential danger to people who interact with elephants. And number of people have got killed through the years. So now if you actually have a sufficient number of telephones and they are in a large enough area that they can interact with each other they have social interactions I think that provides perhaps the best possible situation for an elephant in captivity If you fall short of that, you already have elephants in captivity, which are maybe single or maybe one or two animals. And you cannot provide for them to have a larger group and the surroundings. In that situation, if the elephant cannot even have that sort of social interaction with people, I think it is a very sad situation for that animal. Prutu, with all these challenges, what's happening to elephants around the world, whether Africa, Asia, Sri Lanka and so on? I mean generally. I think elephants are symptomatic of all the other species. Most other species, as you know, are doing pretty badly and doing well every day. It's only a very, very few species who have managed to live with us. Things like cockroaches and rats and things like that are doing pretty well. But all the animals, all the other animals, most of them are doing badly and was on a day by day basis. So with elephants, for any animal, I mean we change the environment so much that most animals can no longer live in that environment. So habitat loss and environment is, I would say, the biggest threat to elephants as well as all these animals. But with elephants, there are additional issues. So with African elephants, a huge problem is deporting for tusks. I mean how pathetic is that? We are killing these majestic animals, we are slaughtering them just for the sake of two teeth. So that is a huge problem in Africa. And then the human elephant conflict, that's probably a bigger problem in Asia than in Africa, but even in Africa it's becoming a bigger problem. and in Asia it's I would say the biggest threat secondary to the habitat loss which is also associated with the conflict for elephants. Well we must hope that with all the signs around us that our humanity will wake up. I think there was even in the last week, there was some terribly disturbing reports about how we are ourselves creating or fueling an existential threat to humanity. But I guess that's a subject of another and much longer podcast. I want to conclude Prutu with an interesting question that I know many will be interested to know the answer to. Are elephants really afraid of mice? Well, elephants, if there was an elephant that had not met a mouse before, he would be very scared of the mouse. Elephants like ourselves, I suppose, like all animals, fear the unknown. So anything that is new, that is strange, that they have not experienced before, they would be scared of. but elephants are also extremely adaptable and pretty intelligent. So in a little while I'm pretty sure that he will overcome his fear of mice. Thank you very much Prutu. Prutu, it's really been an honor chatting with you. You are an incredibly accomplished person with tremendous integrity in the field and I'm really privileged that we are able to share your thoughts in this conversation with our audience. Prutu, thank you very much. We are honored to have had you on the show and I wish you a wonderful weekend. Thank you very much, Dylan. It's been a pleasure.
Summary: Dr. Preeti Viraj Fernando (Prutu) earned a medical degree, a PhD in genetic ecology and conservation of the Asian elephant at Oregon University, and conducted research on Asian elephants and Javan rhinos at Columbia University

Video Title: Merrill: A Life Devoted to Tea- Blessing and a Privilege
Transcript: I was 20 years old when I started my life in tea and I cannot quite comprehend how my love for tea has impacted so many lives. I really labored on my journey because so few people believed in what I was doing and most opposed me. I don't believe they were being unkind just that they were part of a system that could not accept the change that I fought for. Looking back, every moment of that journey taught me a number of lessons from which I have benefited greatly. It is wonderful to know that so many around the world enjoy my Dilma tea. Beyond that is the joy I have in knowing that together my family, my team and have been blessed by God to positively impact the lives of thousands. That is a very special privilege.
Summary: The speaker began working in the tea industry at age 20, developing a product called “Dilma tea.” Early in the venture, they encountered opposition from a system resistant to change, but persisted despite limited support. Their efforts have since reached a global audience, with thousands of consumers reporting positive experiences. The speaker attributes the success to collaboration with family and team members and considers it a privileged impact.

Video Title: Merrill : A Life Devoted to Tea- Kindness to the Planet
Transcript: My family business has an enduring connection with nature because it is the soil and climate that produce the taste and goodness in tea. As a tea grower, I care for my tea from the nursery to yoga. Yet every farmer comes to the realization that it is heaven and earth that crafts tea and and gives it to man. And our role is only to finish what nature has done in the leaf. Nature is threatened. That means humankind too. It is not the responsibility of governments, scientists to fix the climate crisis. It's all of us collectively, business included. There is no plan B and failure isn't an option. I am thrilled to see conservation, sustainable agricultural and environmental efforts of Dilma Conservation. We share these learnings so that other businesses may benefit. Nature sustains life from the air we breathe to the water that we need to survive. It is not hard to see why we have an obligation to protect nature and coexist respectfully. If I wasn't a tea grower, I would still be telling you the same.
Summary: The speaker, a tea grower from a family business, emphasizes that soil and climate determine tea quality and that the farmer’s role is to complete nature’s work on the leaf. They argue that climate and biodiversity threats require collective action, not solely government or scientific solutions, and that failure is unacceptable. The speaker praises the conservation, sustainable agriculture, and environmental initiatives of Dilma Conservation and seeks to share those practices with other businesses. They assert a universal obligation to protect nature for human survival.

Video Title: Merrill: A Life Devoted to Tea -Kindness to People
Transcript: I could never imagine a world where inequality would be so pronounced. My greatest pleasure and privilege are the work of the MJF's Charitable Foundation. It has shown me what our world could be. I cannot understand why every business cannot be built around kindness. It would make the people that run them and their customers happier. We have children of tea pickers who are lawyers, judges, doctors, architects, chefs, and prominent in other professions. Children and youth with development disorders cared for and nurtured. Thousands of aspiring rural entrepreneurs helped in realizing their dreams. This is the significance that every successful business should endeavor to aspire. Profit is temporary. It can never replace the fulfillment of changing someone's life.
Summary: The speaker highlights the work of the MJF Charitable Foundation, which supports children of tea pickers who have become lawyers, judges, doctors, architects, chefs, and other professionals. The foundation also provides care and development for youth with developmental disorders and has assisted thousands of aspiring rural entrepreneurs in realizing their businesses. It emphasizes that profit is temporary, while changing lives offers lasting fulfillment.

Video Title: Merrill: A Life Devoted to Tea- A Better Life for All
Transcript: I was born into a simple rural family. The influence of my parents, especially my mother, and my faith in God molded my character. The primary lessons I learned are humility, kindness, and honesty. Our tea industry was born into an exploitative colonial system. We cannot change history but we can change the present. Our tea industry supports over 2 million people directly and indirectly. I want them all to have a better life. We can achieve that by breaking out the unfair international trading system by going straight to the farmer, the farmer who loves tea and dreams of a better future for their families and the community. That is why I made my Dilma a business that serves humanity, not for profit, but for a better future for all.
Summary: The speaker was raised in a rural family, citing parental influence—particularly from their mother—and personal faith as shaping their values of humility, kindness, and honesty. They note that the regional tea industry operates within an exploitative colonial framework yet supports more than two million people directly and indirectly. To address this, they propose bypassing the unfair international trading system by connecting consumers directly with tea‑growing farmers. Accordingly, they founded a venture called Dilma, described as a non‑profit enterprise aimed at improving the livelihoods of farmers and their communities.

Video Title: Merrill: A Life Devoted to Tea -The right way or the profitable way
Transcript: When I started in tea, there were hundreds of family companies, each passionate about quality and freshness, focused entirely on bringing you fine quality tea. I could never imagine a time when they would be acquired by some giant traders in tea. Sadly, that has happened. It has made my sons, my grandchildren and I more and more determined to fulfill the purpose behind our family business. That is the foundation of my Dilma. Today people who neither know nor care about tea make decisions about tea. Sitting in one country contract packing their teas in another using tea from wherever it is cheap purely for profit that's not good for tea or for you for people who work so hard to make good tea or for tea drinkers who expect a cup of good taste and good health every business must honor the people that nurture it it's the right thing to do
Summary: The speaker observes that the tea sector has moved from hundreds of family‑owned companies dedicated to quality and freshness to consolidation by large trading firms, prompting his family to reaffirm the purpose of their own business, Dilma. He criticizes current practices in which unrelated parties contract‑pack tea across borders using the cheapest sources solely for profit, arguing that this harms tea quality, the workers who produce it, and consumers seeking taste and health benefits. He asserts that any tea business should honor the people who nurture the product.

Video Title: Merrill: A Life Devoted to Tea
Transcript: It's 70 long years since I started to pursue my love for tea. Nearly 33 years since I first invited you to try my tea. Do try it. Summary: The speaker has pursued a passion for tea for 70 years and began inviting others to try their product 33 years ago, marking the first instance of a farm selling tea directly from source to consumers. Their model emphasizes growing, harvesting, processing, and packaging the tea at the origin to deliver it as fresh as possible, citing higher flavor and antioxidant content. The business aims to channel earnings toward supporting the national economy and its workers. The brand positions its offering around taste, natural benefits, and ethical purpose.

Video Title: Discover a unique story of sustainability by Dilmah Tea
Transcript: Every business has an obligation to share its success with those in need. As a company that is committed to support the people and planet, we knew something wasn't just right about our packaging. We wanted to grow our business, but not at the cost of the planet. In the year 2000, we came up with a simple but solid idea. We completely got rid of the plastic and converted 80% of our tea packages to tear strip. This helped us a lot to eliminate the amount of plastic we were giving away to the environment. Today, we are close to eliminating plastics from all our products. Through our Biodiversity Sri Lanka initiative, we're inspiring and helping other businesses to understand the importance of sustainability. We are a small family business and we cannot do this alone, but we have to do more.
Summary: In 2000 the company eliminated plastic from its tea packaging, converting 80 % of its tea packages to tear‑strip material. The firm reports that it is now close to removing plastics from all of its products. Through its Biodiversity Sri Lanka initiative, it aims to educate and support other businesses on sustainability practices. The organization describes itself as a small family‑owned business.

Video Title: Tea in tune with you. Tea in tune with what matters – a Dilmah story
Transcript: The unique geographical heritage of Sri Lanka, its topology, climate and soil, makes it an ideal land where any crop can be grown. Dilma tea is made in the traditional artisanal manner, which requires meticulous care with a personal touch each step of the way. Each leaf that goes into Dilma tea is plucked by hand. The tea leaves are rolled to rupture the leaf cells and allow the cell sap to mix, starting the process of oxidisation. The rolled leaves are spread onto ceramic beds and left to ferment, where the unique flavours and quality of the tea is developed. The doors are passed through the dryer at a temperature of 90 to 95 degrees Celsius. Dilma tea is packed at source, preserving all its natural goodness. It is a business built on quality, authenticity, ethics and integrity. Dilma cares for your tea. From the nursery to your cup. Tea in tune with you. Tea in tune with what matters.
Summary: Sri Lanka’s diverse topography, climate, and soil support the cultivation of many crops, including the tea produced by Dilma. Dilma tea is manufactured using a traditional artisanal process: leaves are hand‑plucked, rolled to rupture cell walls, then spread on ceramic beds to ferment, and finally dried at 90–95 °C before being packed at the source. The company emphasizes quality, authenticity, ethical practices, and integrity throughout production. All processing steps are performed locally, preserving the tea’s natural characteristics.

Summary: Chai is an Ayurvedic beverage made from Camellia sinensis tea combined with traditional spices such as star anise, cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, and nutmeg, a practice attributed to royalty a thousand years ago within a 6,000‑year pharmacopoeia. At the Dilma School of Tea, Ajit from the Tea Lounge by Dilma demonstrates a standard preparation: sealed fresh tea is brewed with boiled water for five minutes, stirred, covered to retain volatile antioxidants, then mixed with condensed milk to achieve a reddish hue indicating a strong brew. Ceylon cinnamon is added and the mixture is oxygenated to produce froth before being poured into a chai mug, displaying visible cinnamon pieces. The method allows customization with alternative milks (oat, almond), sweeteners (local honey), and additional aromatics such as lemongrass, ginger, or pandan leaf,
